Issues.Title: DataBinding: incompatible data type conversion shows no reaction
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

If a DataBinding is created between two properties of incompatible data types, nothing happens at runtime, so it's harder to find the causing problem.
I bind a property of a control to a property of a class via a BindingSource.
If the data types of the properties fit, everything is fine. If they doesn't fit, the setter of the property won't be reached. But there is also no exception about the problem. Neither when not-reaching the setter nor at the app start to tell be that a DataBinding problem exists.

### Steps to reproduce

Test project:
[WinFormsNetVB.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/14552002/WinFormsNetVB.zip)
- start the app
- click the button
- the setters of both properties of the `Foo` class will be reached
- stop the app
- change the code: in the class `Foo`, change the type of the field `_ClassB` and the property `ClassB` from `ClassB` to `ClassA`
![CodeChange](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/49878115/a3389be5-d542-4202-a5ec-14d2493ccea8)
- start the app
- click the button
- the setter of the `ClassB` property of the `Foo` class will **not** be reached. There is also no exception message.


I expect an exception that tells me, that the data bound properties are type-incompatible, either when setting the data binding (mostly at app start) or at least when the magic of data binding will be activated after changing one of the bound properties.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "DataBinding: incompatible data type conversion shows no reaction" (#11020)

Issues.Title: Designer not loading: System.InvalidOperationException: Designer load encountered an error. Please ensure that the project can be built successfully.
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2022 (64-bit) - Preview
Version 17.10.0 Preview 1.0

### .NET version

.NET 8.0

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>WinExe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net8.0-windows</TargetFramework>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
    <UseWindowsForms>true</UseWindowsForms>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
  </PropertyGroup>

</Project>
```

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

Can't recall it worked

### Issue description

Following commands were already exceuted.
```
Add-MpPreference -ExclusionProcess 'devenv.exe'
Add-MpPreference -ExclusionProcess 'DesignToolsServer.exe'
```

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/5653381/fe457013-1c2f-42c4-b3b9-ef584a6f11ce)

However, closing Visual Studio and reopening seems to solve the issue.

1. Create a Windows Forms Application

Issues.Title: Winforms supported OS versions less than Windows XP SP2, Server 2003
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Is it necessary to throw a specific exception or output a specific debug message on OS’s less than Windows XP SP2, Server 2003. If not it would eliminate some VB runtime code that can’t be easily tested and will never be hit and it would improve code coverage. The code will still throw an exception but not with a specific message.

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

If .Net Core runs on versions of Windows less than Windows XP SP2, Server 2003 then yes in that it throws a specific exception saying this VB runtime function doesn’t work.


### Issue description

On OS versions less than Windows XP SP2, Server 2003 there are runtime tests, messages and exceptions in VB runtime that say specific network features don’t work. I would like to eliminate all this code that can’t be tested.

### Steps to reproduce

If .Net 9.0 runs on very old versions of windows the current code will throw exceptions and tests will fail, with proposed changes the exceptions will be different and much less obvious and I would not make any changes. I would include changes in existed PR, since on no current platform that tests are run throw these exceptions it would improv coverage.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Winforms supported OS versions less than Windows XP SP2, Server 2003" (#11004)

Issues.Title: FolderBrowserDialog Allow VirtualFolders through property similar to ShowPinnedPlaces
Issues.Body:
### Background and motivation
Regrding FolderBrowserDialog 
For already existing cloud sync engine applications using shell namespace will it be possible to show virtual folders or is there alternative workaround for this?
Is it possible to add property similar to ShowPinnedPlaces for VirtualFolders so developer can choose to show or hide.
In net framework 4.8 FolderBrowserDialog  virtual foders shown but there is no ShowPinnedPlaces.

### API Proposal

```csharp
namespace System.Windows.Forms;

public sealed class FolderBrowserDialog : CommonDialog
{
   public bool ShowVirtualFolders
    {
        get => !GetOption(FOS_HIDESHELLNAMESPACES_VirtualFolders); // I don't know if such winapi available
        set => SetOption((FOS_HIDESHELLNAMESPACES_VirtualFolders, !value); // I don't know if such winapi available
    }
}
```


### API Usage

```csharp
           var dlg = new System.Windows.Forms.FolderBrowserDialog();
            dlg.ShowVirtualFolders = true;
```


### Alternative Designs

_No response_

### Risks

_No response_

### Will this feature affect UI controls?

FolderBrowserDialog will get affected
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "FolderBrowserDialog Allow VirtualFolders through property similar to ShowPinnedPlaces " (#11001)

Issues.Title: ComboBox: disabled text color is not contrasting enough with the selection background color
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net 9.0 SDK: 9.0.100-preview.3.24128.12

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No
It is working on Windows server 2016 

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

It is not a regression issue, can repro in .Net framework 3.5 to .Net framework 4.8.1 and .Net versions

For ComboBox: disabled text color is not contrasting enough with the selection background color as following screenshot:
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/279dab0b-37c6-4555-b2b6-eb45042d10b7)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .Net application with ComboBox added
2. Set ComboBox's Text property and write some code to disable it and select its Text:
```
comboBox1.SelectionStart = 0;
comboBox1.SelectionLength = comboBox1.Text.Length;
comboBox1.Enabled = false;
```
3. Build and run to observe the ComboBox's Text

Testing sample: 
[ComboBoxSample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/14492730/ComboBoxSample.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ComboBox: disabled text color is not contrasting enough with the selection background color" (#10993)
